importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on the UN's call for improved global disaster alerts in response to worsening extreme weather events.

This date references the occurrence of a glacier collapse in the Swiss village of Blatten, which was predicted through early monitoring and served as a real-world example of the importance of early-warning systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The global surge in extreme weather events, such as floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, all occurred in 2025, emphasizing the urgency of early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—particularly in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of fatalities in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the past 50 years, highlighting the scale of climate-driven risk.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), 50% of assessed countries have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is worst in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being seen in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action and save lives; the WMO emphasizes empowering communities to respond proactively.
A real-world example of successful early warning is the Swiss glacier collapse prediction in May 2025, which allowed evacuation of Blatten village.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), under the UN, has issued a global call to action to address critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather events. Despite progress in early-warning adoption, nearly half of all countries still lack adequate systems, with the majority of weather-related deaths occurring in developing nations. The article highlights real-world examples such as deadly floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, all occurring in 2025. It emphasizes that climate change is intensifying weather extremes, with a notable example being the successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten in May 2025 after a glacier collapse was predicted through monitoring. The WMO stresses that early warning systems are vital not just for alerting populations, but for enabling timely action to save lives and protect infrastructure, especially in vulnerable and conflict-affected regions.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
